Graphical abstract As the demand for hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) increases across various industries, there is a growing need for eco-friendly production process to replace the energy-intensive and environmentally polluting anthraquinone process. In particular, the electrochemical production of H2O2 via the two-electron oxygen reduction reaction (2e-ORR) is being highlighted as a promising alternative. However, achieving high selectivity for 2e-ORR over the four-electron reduction reaction (4e-ORR), remains challenging. We introduce an integrative strategy that combines active motifs-based design with a machine learning to discover promising catalysts for electrochemical H2O2 production. Inspired by single-site alloys that destabilize the binding strength of O* adsorbate, thereby improving the 2e-ORR selectivity, we expanded the chemical space through elemental substitution and efficiently explored this expanded chemical space using machine learning methods. By employing these approaches, we discovered active, selective and stable 2e-ORR catalysts that are not present in the existing database and demonstrated better stability compared to the materials within the database. This work highlights the potential of integrating active motifs-based catalyst design with machine learning to efficiently explore the vast chemical space, accelerating the discovery of novel catalysts. Keywords Electrocatalysts Density Functional Theory Calculations Machine Learning Hydrogen Peroxide Oxygen Reduction Reaction High-throughput Screening Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The demand for hydrogen peroxide (H2O2),a crucial reagent in various industries such as food processing, pulp, paper, and bleaching, continues to rise steadily.[1–4] Electrochemical production of H2O2 through selective electrochemical oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) presents a desirable alternative to the energy-intensive and centralized anthraquinone process. The traditional anthraquinone method generates organic wastes and poses environmental concerns.[5–7] In contrast, electrochemical synthesis of H2O2 via a two-electron oxygen reduction reaction (2e-ORR) is advantageous for on-site and on-demand production. It is particularly notable for its environmental benefits as it uses atmospheric O2 and aqueous environments.[8] However, the 2e-ORR faces challenges due to competition with the four-electron ORR (4e-ORR), which yields water as a product. Overcoming this selectivity challenge is crucial for achieving optimal efficiency in H2O2 electrosynthesis. Electrochemical O2 reduction can proceed via two distinct pathways: 2e-ORR (eq. (1a) and (1b) and 4e-ORR (eq. (2a)-d), leading to the production of H2O2 and H2O, respectively. (1a) O 2 + 2 H + + e - → OOH * + ( H + + e - ) (1b) OOH * + ( H + + e - ) → H 2 O 2 + ∗ (2a) O 2 + 4 H + + e - → OOH * + 3 H + + e - (2b) OOH * + 3 ( H + + e - ) → O * + 2 H + + e - + H 2 O (2c) O * + 2 H + + e - → OH * + H + + e - (2d) OH * + ( H + + e - ) → H 2 O + ∗ The pathway taken depends on the properties of the catalyst, highlighting the significance of a detailed understanding of the reaction mechanisms that govern the selective 2e-/4e-ORR processes for efficient H2O2 production. This understanding is crucial for the design of active and selective catalysts. [9–11] As outlined in the reaction steps, the initial step for both pathways is identical: the protonation of O2 to form OOH* (O2 → OOH*). The product selectivity, yielding either H2O2 or H2O, is determined by the subsequent protonation of OOH*, which either forms H2O2 or O* adsorbate. Thus, a strategy to fine-tune product selectivity for H2O2 involves modulating the adsorption strength of O*.[10] To achieve this goal, Siahrostami et al. reported an alloying strategy to modify the adsorption site of the O* adsorbate. Contrary to the hollow O* binding site observed on pure Pt (111), the incorporation of oxophobic Hg led to a shift in the O* binding site to the Pt-top site. This alteration weakened O* binding and thereby enhanced the selectivity for H2O2.[9] Following this design principle, [10] Back et al. conducted high-throughput screening (HTS) by collecting bulk data from the Materials Project database. [12] Various properties, including thermodynamic, electrochemical stability, as well as catalytic activity and selectivity were evaluated. Based on these evaluations, several promising candidate catalysts were identified and proposed. Subsequent experimental validations of these candidates were also reported. [13,14] It should be noted, however, that the chemical space explored is confined to the existing database. This limitation poses a challenge in discovering catalysts that have not yet been reported. To tackle this problem, we integrated various strategies to devise an active motifs-based catalyst design approach combined with machine learning. We expanded the dataset by applying elemental substitutions, thereby broadening the chemical diversity of the catalysts. Building on previous work by Back et al., which suggested that catalytic active motifs with a large proportion of oxophobic elements exhibit high selectivity for H2O2 production. [10,13,14] We substituted a combination of oxophobic and oxophilic elements in a collection of active motifs (Fig. 1 a, b). All the properties of the new catalysts generated by elemental substitution, including stability, activity and selectivity, were initially evaluated using machine learning models. [15,16] The details of the machine learning models used for predicting stability, activity, and selectivity are provided in the Supplementary Notes. Finally, we validated these promising active motifs through DFT calculations and proposed novel electrocatalysts that have not been previously listed in the database. These findings highlight the effectiveness of our approach in discovering new catalysts. 2 Methods 2.1 Calculation details Spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed using Vienna ab-initio simulation package (VASP, version 5.4.4). [17,18] To ensure a compatibility of DFT calculations for bulk structures, we used the identical VASP parameters and pseudopotentials to those in the Materials Project (MP) (PBE exchange–correlation functional and old-PBE based pseudopotentials). [12] To calculate binding energies of adsorbates, we employed the Revised Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (RPBE) [19] functional. The cutoff energy of 400 eV was adopted, and the convergence criteria for energy and force were set to 10-4 eV and 0.05 eV/Å, respectively. Monkhorst-pack k-points were sampled, with k-points (k1 × k2 × k3) for bulk and (k1 × k2 × 1) for surface structures. These values were determined to satisfy the conditions 30 Å < an × kn (n = 1, 2, 3) for bulk and 25 Å < an × kn (n = 1, 2) for surface, where a1, a2 and a3 are the lengths of the unit vectors in x, y and z directions. [20] We included a vacuum spacing of at least 15 Å along the z-axis for surface structures. We employed the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) method to calculate the Gibbs free energy of a proton-electron pair i.e., G(H+ + e−) = ½ G(H2) at standard conditions. [21] The effect of the applied potential (U) was included as G(H+ + e−) = ½ G(H2) – eU, where e is the elementary charge of an electron and U is the electrode potential versus the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). The DFT energies were converted into the Gibbs free energies by adding correction values calculated using the harmonic oscillator (absorbates) and the ideal-gas (gas molecules) approximations as implemented in Atomic Simulation Environment (ASE) ( Table S1 ). [22] We note that the Gibbs free energy correction value for the top site O* binding is 0.00 eV, which differs from that of the hollow site, +0.06 eV. To consider the effect of solvent stabilization, we added −0.25 eV to ΔGOOH* considering a half-dissociated water structure on the catalyst surfaces. [23–25] The adsorption Gibbs free energies of oxygenated species (ΔGO* andΔGOOH*) were referenced toH2 andH2Omolecules and calculated as follows: (3a) Δ G O ∗ = E O ∗ - E ∗ - E H 2 O + E H 2 + G corr , O ∗ (3b) Δ G OOH ∗ = E OOH ∗ - E ∗ - 2 E H 2 O + 3 2 E H 2 + G corr , O O H ∗ where E ∗ , E O ∗ and E OOH ∗ correspond to DFT energies of the bare catalyst surface, O* and OOH* adsorbed surfaces, respectively. E H 2 and E H 2 O denote DFT energies of H2 and H2O molecules in the 15 × 15 × 15 Å3 cell. 2.2 Property evaluations 2.2.1 Catalytic activity and selectivity We predicted the ΔGOOH* and ΔGO* using DSTAR (DFT & Structure-free Active motif based Representation) model to evaluate the catalytic activity and selectivity for 2e-ORR (Fig. 1 c). In this model, only the active motifs consisting of binding sites and their first nearest neighbor atoms are converted into machine learning inputs, without considering all atoms in surface structures. The active motifs are categorized into three types of sites: FNN (first nearest neighboring atoms of the binding site), SNNsame (the second nearest neighboring atoms of the binding site in the same layer), and SNNsub (the second nearest neighboring atoms of the binding site in the sublayer). All possible combinations of these categorized sites were enumerated as machine learning inputs to predict ΔGOOH* and ΔGO*. More details about the model can be found in Ref [16,26] and in the Supplementary Note 1. To train DSTAR models, we utilized a dataset from our previous study, consisting of 1,821 single-site alloy surface structures with ΔGOOH*.[10] This dataset was concatenated with the Generalized Adsorption Simulator for Python (GASpy) dataset generated by Ulissi et al. [27], which contains 2,281 unique surface structures with OOH* adsorbate and 3,226 unique surface structures with O* adsorbate. The accuracy of the models was evaluated using a 5-fold cross-validation strategy. The hyperparameters of the trained model are summarized in Table S3 . The catalytic activity of 2e-ORR was evaluated by calculating the overpotential (η) using ΔGOOH*. The η values were calculated as Δ G OOH ∗ - 4.22 e V / e , where smaller η indicates higher catalytic activity (Fig. 1 c). To predict the product selectivity of H2O2, we employed a thermodynamic descriptor, ΔΔG, developed by Siahrostami et al.[11,28] This descriptor is derived from ΔGOOH* and ΔGO*, resulting in a single metric (eqn. 3–5). The ΔΔG was calculated by subtracting G2 from G1. A smaller ΔΔG indicates higher 2e-ORR selectivity, with the maximum selectivity achieved when ΔΔG approaches zero (Fig. 1 c). (4) G 1 = Δ G H 2 O 2 - Δ G OOH ∗ (5) G 2 = Δ G O ∗ + H 2 O - Δ G OOH ∗ (6) Δ Δ G = G 1 - G 2 2.2.2 Thermodynamic and electrochemical stability The new crystal bulk structures generated by elemental substitution are unrelaxed. To predict the formation energy (Ef) of these unrelaxed bulk structures, we employed a direction-based crystal graph convolutional neural network (D-CGCNN), [15] which builds upon the CGCNN developed by Xie and Grossman. [29] This model incorporates discrete directional information, which is more invariant than atomic coordinates offering enhanced performance in predicting the Ef of unrelaxed structures. Further details on the D-CGCNN are available in Supplementary Note 2 and Ref.15 The predicted Ef were used to determine the energy above the convex hull (Ehull) and the Pourbaix decomposition energy (ΔGpbx). The Ehull values of materials were calculated as the relative formation energy with respect to the convex hull line ( E f convex ) as follow: (7) E hull = E f - E f convex The Pourbaix diagrams were constructed using the Materials Project (MP) Pourbaix diagram framework developed by Persson et al., [30] as implemented in Pymatgen.[31] For the given chemical compositions, the Pourbaix diagram determines the most stable phase under specific electrochemical conditions by considering all possible equilibrium redox reactions. For the redox reaction i.e., R e a c t a n t s + H 2 O ⇔ P r o d u c t s + m H + + n e - , the Gibbs free energy change of the redox reaction ( Δ G r ) can be expressed by: (8) Δ G r = Δ G r ° + 2.303 × R T × l o g a Reactants a Products - 2.303 × m × R T × p H (9) Δ G r ° = μ product ° + μ H + ° - μ reactant ° - μ H 2 O ° where Δ G r ° is the standard Gibbs free energy change at standard conditions, and F, R, T and a are the Faraday constant, gas constant, temperature, and activity coefficient, respectively. The standard chemical potential ( μ ° ) can be expressed by: (10) μ ° = H ° - T S ° = E DFT + E ZPE + δ H - T S ° where E ZPE , δ H and T S ° are the zero-point energy, integrated heat capacity and entropy contribution at the standard condition. The E ZPE and δ H for both solid and gas species were neglected assuming that these energies have similar contributions between species and therefore cancel out in reaction energies. [32] For solid phase species, the entropy contribution is neglected since its contribution is too small compared to the gas species. The chemical potential values were collected from MP. To obtain the raw DFT energy of solids for the Gibbs free energy calculations in Eq. (9) and (10), we utilized the relationship between the ML-predicted formation energy ( E f ML ) and the predicted raw DFT energy ( E DFT , p r e d ). The E DFT , p r e d of materials can be derived from the E f ML as follows: (11) E DFT , p r e d = E f ML × N + ∑ i = 1 N μ ° n i where N and μ ° n i are the number of atoms in the material and the chemical potential of ith atom, respectively. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalyst surface generations Since it is unlikely to discover novel catalysts with desired properties by exploring existing databases due to limited chemical space diversity [26,33], we expanded the chemical space using the active motif-based DSTAR models. [16] Specifically, we substituted elements within active motifs.Further details on the DSTAR can be found in the 'Supplementary Note 1: Machine Learning for Expanding Chemical Space and Predicting Binding Energy’. Among the concatenated database, we identified 3,101 unique active motifs. Building on the concept that incorporating oxophobic elements around oxophilic active sites enhances performance in the 2e-ORR process, [9,34] we enumerated promising bimetallic combinations of oxophilic and oxophobic elements using the unique active motifs (Fig. 1 b). For oxophilic element candidates, we selected 29 elements frequently observed on active surface in our dataset. The oxophobic elements were taken from the previous study. [10] The oxophilic and oxophobic elements are demonstrated in Figure S4 . Halogen elements were excluded due to their heuristically observed instability during DFT calculations. Ultimately, we generated a total of 719,432 active motifs. The details of the chemical space expansion process are demonstrated in Fig. 2 b. 3.2 Screening for activity and selectivity We trained two DSTAR models to predict key DFT binding energies (ΔEOOH*, ΔEO*). The trained models demonstrated reasonable accuracy, with MAE values of 0.194 eV and 0.325 eV for ΔEOOH* and for ΔEO*, respectively ( Figure S1 ). These DFT binding energies were converted into the Gibbs free binding energies (ΔG) by adding correction values. While these accuracies could potentially be improved using more sophisticated graph-based deep learning models, [35,36] our descriptor-based models offer two advantages. First, these models do not require complete surface atomic structures, allowing active motifs of all possible elemental combinations to be generated very quickly. Additionally, the training and prediction processes for descriptor-based models are much more efficient than those of graph-based models, thereby facilitating the exploration of vast chemical spaces. The overall screening procedure is illustrated in Fig. 2 a We evaluated 2e-ORR selectivity and activity using the thermodynamic descriptors, i.e., ΔΔG and η, respectively (Fig. 1 c). Although smaller ΔΔG predicts higher 2e-ORR selectivity, we adopted a criterion of 0.65 eV for ΔΔG. This value was chosen based on the PtHg4, which has a ΔΔG of 0.65 eV, and has demonstrated high H2O2 selectivity.[9] For the activity criterion, we set the threshold to 4.22 eV for ΔGOOH*, which corresponds to an ideal catalyst with η = 0.0 V. Considering the MAE values of approximately 0.20 eV for ΔGOOH* and ΔGO*, we selected surfaces within the range of 4.02 e V ≤ Δ G OOH ∗ ≤ 4.42 e V and Δ Δ G ≤ 0.65 e V . Through this process, we identified 35,096 promising active motifs among 719,432. 3.3 Screening for bulk stability Once we identified the promising active motifs, we generated the corresponding bulk structures and evaluated their bulk stability. This was feasible because all active motifs have their bulk structure data available. From the initial 35,096 surfaces that satisfy the criteria for ΔGOOH* and ΔGO*, we constructed 6,355 bulk structures. The formation energy (Ef) and the energy above the convex hull (Ehull) were used as descriptors of thermodynamic stability, [33,37] while the ΔGpbx value at U = 0.7 VRHE and pH = 0 was used as a descriptor of electrochemical stability. [34,38] Lower values of the descriptors indicate greater stability. The stability screening criteria were set as follows: Ef ≤ 0 eV/atom, Ehull ≤ 0.1 eV/atom, and ΔGpbx ≤ 0.5 eV/atom. [39] (Fig. 3 a and 3c). We predicted the thermodynamic and electrochemical stability of candidates using the D-CGCNN model. [15] The pre-trained D-CGCNN model achieved MAE of 0.299 eV/atom for Ef predictions. Based on the predicted Ef values, we derived stability metrics such as Ehull and ΔGpbx. Considering the prediction errors of the ML model, we adjusted the criteria to account for MAE, thereby loosening the stability thresholds as follows: Ef ≤ 0.3 eV/atom, Ehull ≤ 0.4 eV/atom, and ΔGpbx ≤ 0.8 eV/atom. Using this approach, we efficiently reduced the number of candidate materials to 1,028. Validation was also performed using DFT calculations, resulting 213 bulk structures satisfying all criteria. (Fig. 3 b and 3d). The 213 bulk structures corresponded to seven elemental combinations, i.e., CdAu, ZnAu, PdHg, PdAu, CuAu, PtHg, PdAg ( Figure S5 ). We confirmed the validity of our HTS approach, as combinations that have been reported as 2e-ORR catalysts such as PdHg [40,41], PdAu [42,43], CuAu [44,45], PtHg [9] and PdAg [46,47] were also identified in this process. From these results, we constructed phase diagrams of the candidates by integrating the calculated Ef values with the MP database and compared the hull lines to existing materials (Fig. 4 a and 4b). Notably, for PdAu and PdHg, we found more stable structures than those in the database ( Table S4 ), demonstrating the effectiveness of our method in discovering new materials. The compositional phase diagrams for the other elemental combinations are presented in Figure S6 . 3.4 Analysis of catalytic properties To evaluate the 2e-ORR performance of the candidate combinations, we calculated ΔGOOH* and ΔGO* for the low index surfaces of the most stable structures in each composition, which are positioned below the original convex hull line. Fig. 4 c demonstrates the catalytic activity and selectivity of PdxHgy and PdxAuy surfaces. Notably, many of the surface structures of these materials fall within the optimal range for 2e-ORR (4.02 eV ≤ ΔGOOH* ≤ 4.42 eV and ΔΔG ≤ 0.65 eV), demonstrating that these discovered surface structures have the potential to serve as effective 2e-ORR catalysts. We further investigated the high catalytic performance of the optimal surfaces within the green shaded area of Fig. 4 c. The atomic structures of the optimal surfaces and the reference Pd (111) surfaces are illustrated in Fig. 5 c. Further details can be found in Table S5 . This analysis focused on the effects of oxophobic atoms around the active site. In agreement with previous studies, [9,10] we observed that the presence of oxophobic atoms around the active site improves activity and selectivity by changing the O* binding site from hollow to top (ensemble effect) and weakening the ΔGO* (ligand effect) thus lowering the ΔΔG (Fig. 5 a). Given that the coordination number (CN) influences absorbate binding, [48] we investigated the impact of the CNphobic on the binding strength of O*. Fig. 5 b shows that an increase in CNphobic leads to a decrease in ΔΔG, making H2O2 formation more favorable. These findings confirmed that engineering the environment around the active site can improve catalyst performance. The surfaces in Fig. 5 b of information are listed in Table S5 . 3.5 Challenges and future directions In this work, we developed an integrated workflow for catalyst discovery that combines machine learning approaches with an elemental substitution strategy. We applied this method to binary alloy systems as a proof-of-concept. Notably, while our method successfully identified new binary structures, but did not discover unprecedented materials due to the restriction of our analysis to binary compositions. Future work should focus on exploring more combinatorial systems, such as ternary or high-entropy alloys, to identify groundbreaking materials. Another limitation of this work is that the expanded dataset was generated based on virtual slab information obtained from elemental substitutions. This introduces uncertainty about the actual existence of the substituted surface due to potential structural disparities between the original and substituted surfaces. Additionally, as we rely on substitutions to expand the dataset, its scope is restricted to the structures and element ratios within the existing database. To address these limitations and enhance the HTS methodology’s reliability and applicability, expanding the database using generative models could be a solution. Genetic Algorithms (GAs), Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) [49,50], diffusion-based model [51] and Large Language Model (LLM) [52,53] are being used to generate crystal or surface structures. These models offer the potential to provide a more diverse exploration of material structures, thus overcoming the drawbacks associated with solely relying on elemental substitution within the existing database. 4 Conclusions In this work, we introduce the HTS method aimed at discovering novel catalysts for 2e-ORR. This method enhances material exploration through two main aspects. Firstly, by leveraging active motifs-based catalyst design, we expanded a dataset by incorporating oxophobic elements around active motifs via elemental substitution, providing a promising starting point for catalyst screening. Second, we utilized ML models to reduce the need for extensive DFT calculations, systematically narrowing down a pool of 7 million surfaces and significantly saving computational resources. The proposed materials were then validated using DFT calculations, confirming their stability and catalytic performance. We successfully identified seven promising elemental combinations for 2e-ORR catalysts. Notably, five of these combinations are already recognized as effective catalysts, validating the effectiveness of our catalyst discovery strategy. The compositional phase diagram generated by integrating the discovered materials with the MP database demonstrated that the discovered materials exhibited higher stability than those in the database. Furthermore, the computed activity and selectivity of 2e-ORR for the stable structures showed the optimal catalytic performance. This study demonstrates the capability of integrated strategy to explore the vast chemical space to discover new catalysts. coredata.dc:description: As the demand for hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) increases across various industries, there is a growing need for eco-friendly production process to replace the energy-intensive and environmentally polluting anthraquinone process. In particular, the electrochemical production of H2O2 via the two-electron oxygen reduction reaction (2e-ORR) is being highlighted as a promising alternative. However, achieving high selectivity for 2e-ORR over the four-electron reduction reaction (4e-ORR), remains challenging. We introduce an integrative strategy that combines active motifs-based design with a machine learning to discover promising catalysts for electrochemical H2O2 production. Inspired by single-site alloys that destabilize the binding strength of O* adsorbate, thereby improving the 2e-ORR selectivity, we expanded the chemical space through elemental substitution and efficiently explored this expanded chemical space using machine learning methods. By employing these approaches, we discovered active, selective and stable 2e-ORR catalysts that are not present in the existing database and demonstrated better stability compared to the materials within the database. This work highlights the potential of integrating active motifs-based catalyst design with machine learning to efficiently explore the vast chemical space, accelerating the discovery of novel catalysts.
